title: 111_hr4346
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Emancipation Commemoration Act of 2009" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The National Emancipation Commemoration Act of 2009 establishes the National Emancipation Commemoration Commission to ensure a national observance of the 150th anniversary of the end of chattel slavery in the US, highlight the protections of the 13th Amendment against modern slavery, develop programs on antebellum and modern slavery, and support related events and activities. The National Emancipation Commemoration Act of 2009 establishes the National Emancipation Commemoration Commission for the observances of the 150th anniversary of Emancipation and the adoption of the Thirteenth Amendment, including commemorative coin, stamp, and related activities. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "commemoration" as events related to the Emancipation Proclamation and Thirteenth Amendment, "Commission" as the established body, and "modern slavery" as activities violating Federal laws. Activities violating Federal laws against slavery and human trafficking are outlined in chapter 77 of title 18, United States Code. The Attorney General will assist in the commemoration. The Attorney General may provide grants and assistance for programs and activities related to the 150th anniversary of Emancipation, encouraging organizations to participate in commemoration events. The curr_chunk discusses the significance of events commemorated by the commemoration, including public scholarly research on chattel slavery, the trans-Atlantic slave trade, historical figures like Abraham Lincoln and Harriet Tubman, the Emancipation, and the modern effects of slavery. It also mentions efforts for a commemorative coin and stamp. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting commemorative activities like coins, stamps, and heritage tourism related to the Underground Railroad. It aims to support economic benefits from tourism and facilitate activities at relevant sites. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission is established to promote activities related to the Underground Railroad, such as coins, stamps, and heritage tourism, to support economic benefits and facilitate activities at relevant sites. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission is established to advise the Attorney General on grants and conduct a study on modern slavery globally and in the United States from 1865 to present, making recommendations to address highlighted issues. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission is required to submit an interim report by January 1, 2013, and a final report by March 2, 2017, detailing their activities, study results, and financial information. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission is composed of 18 members, including the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights as the Chair, the Ambassador at Large as the Vice-Chair, and the Librarian of Congress or a designee. The Commission is required to submit a final accounting of funds, study results, and any findings/recommendations. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission includes members such as the Director of the National Park Service, the Director of the National Museum of American History, the Director of the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center, the Director of the National Civil Rights Museum, and the Executive Director of the National Hispanic Cultural Center. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission includes members appointed by various leaders and organizations, with terms lasting for the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission appoints members to fill vacancies for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Meetings are held at least twice a year and voting is conducted by the majority of members. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission requires an affirmative majority vote for decision-making and a majority for a quorum. The Commission has the power to accept donations, appoint advisory committees, authorize actions, and procure supplies. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission has the authority to enter into contracts, leases, and legal agreements to fulfill its duties. Commission members serve without compensation, except for federal employees who receive their regular compensation. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission allows for travel expenses and per diem for members and employees while on duty. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment requires approval by a majority of Commission members, and the Chairperson can set their compensation without regard to certain pay regulations. The executive director and personnel of the National Emancipation Commemoration Commission cannot be paid more than the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail their personnel to assist the Commission as needed. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission can accept personnel from States and reimburse them. They can also use voluntary services and the Attorney General will provide administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. The National Emancipation Commemoration Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. The Commission and any advisory committees established under this Act will terminate on September 30, 2017.
